introduction.p:
In Chapter we developed the concept of the derivative of a function. We now know that the derivative f' of a function f measures the instantaneous rate of change of f with respect to x. The derivative also tells us the slope of the tangent line to the graph of y=f(x) at any given value of x. So far, we have focused on interpreting the derivative graphically or, in the context of a physical setting, as a meaningful rate of change. To calculate the value of the derivative at a specific point, we have relied on the limit definition of the derivative:
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} .

In this chapter we investigate how the limit definition of the derivative leads to interesting patterns and rules that enable us to quickly find a formula for f'(x) without directly using the limit definition. For example, we would like to apply shortcuts to differentiate a function such as g(x) = 4x^7 - \sin(x) + 3e^x.

statement.p:
Functions of the form f(x) = x^n, where n = 1, 2, 3, \ldots, are often called power functions. functionpower function The first two questions below revisit work we did earlier in Chapter, and the following questions extend those ideas to higher powers of x.
Use the limit definition of the derivative to find F'(x) for F(x) = x^2.
Use the limit definition of the derivative to find g'(x) for g(x) = x^3.
Use the limit definition of the derivative to find G'(x) for G(x) = x^4. (Hint: (a+b)^4 = a^4 + 4a^3b + 6a^2b^2 + 4ab^3 + b^4. Apply this rule to (x+h)^4 within the limit definition.)
Based on your work in (a), (b), and (c), what do you conjecture is the derivative of m(x) = x^5? Of p(x) = x^{13}?
Conjecture a formula for the derivative of f(x) = x^n that holds for any positive integer n. That is, given f(x) = x^n where n is a positive integer, what do you think is the formula for f'(x)?

ol.li: m'(x)=5x^4 when m(x)=x^5; when p(x)=x^{13}, then p'(x)=13x^{12}.
f'(x)=nx^{n-1}, where f(x)=x^n and n is a positive integer.

ol.label: a

li.p: In the previous parts, we discovered that the derivatives of x^2, x^3, and x^4 are 2x, 3x^2, and 4x^3, respectively. It looks like when we increase the power of x by one, this affects the derivative by increasing both the coefficient and the power of x by one. For instance, going from F(x)=x^2 to g(x)=x^3, we saw the derivatives go from F'(x)=2x to g'(x)=3x^2.

Since the derivative of x^4 is 4x^3, if this pattern continues, then it makes sense for the derivative of x^5 to be 5x^4. Then if p(x)=x^{13}, we've increased the power of x by eight from x^5, so we want to increase the coefficient and power in the derivative by eight as well, to get p'(x)=(5+8)x^{4+8}=13x^{12}.

ol.li: The pattern we've seen is that increasing the power of x by one makes the coefficient and power of x in the derivative by one. Also, the power of x in the derivative is one less than in the original function in each case we've looked at, and the coefficient on the derivative is the same as the power in the original function. For instance, m(x)=x^5 implies m'(x)=5x^4=5x^{5-1}. If we try to generalize this by replacing 5 with n, we conjecture that when n is a positive integer and f(x)=x^n, then f'(x)=nx^{n-1}.

subsection.title: Some Key Notation
subsection.p:
We use a variant of this notation as the instruction to take the derivative. In particular,
\frac{d}{dx}\left[ \Box \right]
means take the derivative of the quantity in \Box with respect to x. For example, we may write \frac{d}{dx}[x^2] = 2x.

It is important to note that the independent variable can be different from x. If we have f(z) = z^2, we then write f'(z) = 2z. Similarly, if y = t^2, we say \frac{dy}{dt} = 2t. And it is also true that \frac{d}{dq}[q^2] = 2q. This notation may also be used for second derivatives: f''(z) = \frac{d}{dz}\left[\frac{df}{dz}\right] = \frac{d^2 f}{dz^2}=\frac{d^2}{dz^2}[f].
In what follows, we'll build a repertoire of functions for which we can quickly compute the derivative.

subsection.title: Constant, Power, and Exponential Functions
subsection.p: So far, we know the derivative formula for two important classes of functions: constant functions and power functions. If f(x) = c is a constant function, its graph is a horizontal line with slope zero at every point. Thus, \frac{d}{dx}[c] = 0. We summarize this with the following rule.

assemblage.title: Derivatives of Constant Functions
assemblage.p: For any real number c, if f(x) = c, then f'(x) = 0.

subsection.p: In your work in Example, you conjectured that for any positive integer n, if f(x) = x^n, then f'(x) = nx^{n-1}. This rule can be formally proved for any positive integer n, and also for any nonzero real number (positive or negative).

assemblage.title: Derivatives of Power Functions
assemblage.p: For any nonzero real number n, if f(x) = x^n, then f'(x) = nx^{n-1}.

statement.p: Using the rule for power functions, we can compute the following derivatives. If g(z) = z^{-3}, then g'(z) = -3z^{-4}. Similarly, if h(t) = t^{\frac{7}{5}}, then \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{7}{5}t^{\frac{2}{5}}, and \frac{d}{dq} [q^{\pi}] = \pi q^{\pi - 1}.

subsection.p: It will be instructive to have a derivative formula for one more type of basic function. For now, we simply state this rule without explanation or justification. We will encounter graphical reasoning for why the rule is plausible in Example, and we will further explore why this rule is true in one of the exercises.

assemblage.title: Derivatives of Exponential Functions
assemblage.p: For any positive real number a, if f(x) = a^x, then f'(x) = a^x \ln(a).

statement.p:
If f(x) = 2^x, then f'(x) = 2^x \ln(2). Similarly, for p(t) = 10^t, p'(t) = 10^t \ln(10). It is especially important to note that when a = e, where e is the base of the natural logarithm function, we have that
\frac{d}{dx} [e^x] = e^x \ln(e) = e^x
since \ln(e) = 1. This is an extremely important property of the function e^x: it is its own derivative!

subsection.p: Note carefully the distinction between power functions and exponential functions: in power functions, the variable is in the base, as in x^2, while in exponential functions, the variable is in the exponent, as in 2^x. As we can see from the rules, this makes a big difference in the form of the derivative.

li.p:
The limit definition of g'(0) says g'(0)=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{g(0+h)-g(0)}{h}=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{2^h-2^0}{h}=\lim_{h\to0}\frac{2^h-1}{h}. We consider this difference quotient at the values h=0.1, h=0.01, and h=0.001, and find that
\frac{2^{0.1}-1}{0.1}\approx\mathstrut \amp 0.7177, \frac{2^{0.01}-1}{0.01}\approx\mathstrut \amp 0.6956, \frac{2^{0.001}-1}{0.001}\approx\mathstrut \amp 0.6933 . Hence we approximate g'(0) by 0.693, which is very close to our slope estimate of 0.71 from (b) for the tangent line to y=g(x) at x=0.

We start with the y-intercept of g' that we found in part (c): the point (0,0.693). Then, since the slope of the tangent line to g at a point x=a is exactly the value of g'(a), we use our slope estimates from (b) to add more points to our graph: (-2,0.17),~ (-1,0.33),~ (1,1.4),~ (2,2.67). Finally, since the graph of y=g(x) is always increasing and concave up, we know the graph of y=g'(x) will be always positive and increasing. Thus we end up with the sketch shown below.

Multiplying a function g by a positive constant c affects the graph of y=g(x) by vertically stretching it if 1\lt c, or by vertically compressing it if 0\lt c\lt 1. The shapes of the graphs of y=g(x) and y=g'(x) are very similar, and it looks like the derivative graph is a slightly flattened version of the graph of y=g(x). This suggests g'(x)=c\cdot g(x) for some constant c between 0 and 1. In particular, we note that \ln(2)\approx0.693. Since this is the approximation we found for g'(0), where g(0)=1, it is reasonable to assume that a formula for g' is g'(x)=\ln(2)\cdot g(x)=2^x\ln(2).

subsection.title: Constant Multiples and Sums of Functions
subsection.p:
Next we will learn how to compute the derivative of a function constructed as an algebraic combination of basic functions. For instance, we'd like to be able to take the derivative of a polynomial function such as
p(t) = 3t^5 - 7t^4 + t^2 - 9 , which is a sum of constant multiples of powers of t. To that end, we develop two new rules: the constant multiple rule and the sum rule.

With the constant multiple rule, we want to answer the question how is the derivative of y = kf(x) related to the derivative of y = f(x)? Recall that when we multiply a function by a constant k, we vertically stretch the graph by a factor of |k| (and reflect the graph across the horizontal line y = 0 if k \lt 0). This vertical stretch affects the slope of the graph, so the slope of the function y = kf(x) is k times as steep as the slope of y = f(x). Thus, when we multiply a function by a factor of k, we change the value of its derivative by a factor of k as well. We note that the constant multiple rule can be formally proved as a consequence of properties of limits, using the limit definition of the derivative.

assemblage.title: The Constant Multiple Rule

subsection.p: In words, this rule says that the derivative of a constant times a function is the constant times the derivative of the function.

statement.p: If g(t) = 3 \cdot 5^t, then Be careful with this one! 3\cdot 5^t is not the same as 15^t. An easy way to see the difference is to substitute t=2 into each expression: g(2)=3\cdot 5^2=3\cdot25=75; whereas 15^2=225. g'(t) = 3 \cdot 5^t \ln(5). Similarly, \frac{d}{dz} [5z^{-2}] = 5 (-2z^{-3})=-10z^{-3}.

subsection.p:
Next we examine a sum of two functions. If we have y = f(x) and y = g(x), we can compute a new function y = (f+g)(x) by adding the outputs of the two functions: (f+g)(x) = f(x) + g(x). Not only is the value of the new function the sum of the values of the two known functions, but the slope of the new function is the sum of the slopes of the known functions. Therefore, Like the constant multiple rule, the sum rule can be formally proved as a consequence of properties of limits, using the limit definition of the derivative.
we arrive at the following sum rule for derivatives:

assemblage.title: The Sum Rule
assemblage.p: derivativesum rule If f(x) and g(x) are differentiable functions with derivatives f'(x) and g'(x) respectively, then \frac{d}{dx}[f(x) + g(x)] = f'(x) + g'(x).

subsection.p: In words, the sum rule tells us that the derivative of a sum is the sum of the derivatives. It also tells us that a sum of two differentiable functions is also differentiable. Furthermore, because we can view the difference function y = (f-g)(x) = f(x) - g(x) as y = f(x) + (-1 \cdot g(x)), the sum rule and constant multiple rules together tell us that \frac{d}{dx}\left[f(x)-g(x)\right]=\frac{d}{dx}\left[f(x) + (-1 \cdot g(x))\right] = f'(x) - g'(x), or that the derivative of a difference is the difference of the derivatives. We can now compute derivatives of sums and differences of elementary functions.

subsection.p: In the same way that we have shortcut rules to help us find derivatives, we introduce some language that is simpler and shorter. Often, rather than say take the derivative of f, we'll instead say simply differentiate f. Similarly, if the derivative exists at a point, we say f is differentiable at that point, or that f can be differentiated there.

As we work with the algebraic structure of functions, it is important to develop a big picture view of what we are doing. Here, we make several general observations based on the rules we have so far.
The derivative of any polynomial function is another polynomial function, and the degree of the derivative is one less than the degree of the original function. For instance, if p(t) = 7t^5 - 4t^3 + 8t, then p is a degree 5 polynomial and its derivative, p'(t) = 35t^4 - 12t^2 + 8, is a degree 4 polynomial.
The derivative of any exponential function is another exponential function: for example, if g(z) = 7 \cdot 2^z, then g'(z) = 7 \cdot 2^z \ln(2), which is also exponential.
We should not lose sight of the fact that everything we developed in Chapter regarding the meaning of the derivative still holds. The derivative measures the instantaneous rate of change of the original function as well as the slope of the tangent line at any selected point on the curve.

P'(4) = 2(1.37)^4 \ln(1.37) \approx 2.218 million cells per day.
The population is growing at an increasing rate.
The slope is a number and is only one piece of the equation, which contains more information.

Note that since h(z) = z^{\frac{1}{2}} + z^{-1}, we have h'(z) = \frac{1}{2}z^{-\frac{1}{2}} - z^{-2}=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{z}}-\frac{1}{z^2}. Thus, h'(4) = \frac{1}{2\sqrt4} - \frac{1}{4^2} = \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{16} = \frac{3}{16}. Therefore the slope of the tangent line to the graph of y=h(z) at the point where z = 4 is \frac{3}{16}.
Note that P'(t) = 2(1.37)^t \ln(1.37), and therefore P'(4) = 2(1.37)^4 \ln(1.37) \approx 2.218 million cells per day.

We can compute P''(t) by taking the derivative of P'(t), and we find that P''(t) = 2(1.37)^t \ln(1.37) \ln(1.37). Then we see that P''(4) \approx 0.69825 is positive, which tells us that P'(t) is increasing at t = 4. Since the instantaneous rate of change of P is (positive and) increasing, it follows that the population is growing at an increasing rate on the fourth day.

Given p(a) = 3a^4 - 2a^3 + 7a^2 - a + 12, first observe that p(-1) = 3 + 2 + 7 + 1 + 12 = 25, so the tangent line will pass through the point (-1,25). Furthermore, since p'(a) = 12a^3 - 6a^2 + 14a - 1, we know that the slope of the tangent line is p'(-1) = -12 - 6 - 14 - 1 = -33. An equation of the tangent line is therefore y - 25 = -33(a+1). Equivalently, y=-33a-8 is an equation of this tangent line.

Finding the slope of the tangent line only requires knowing the value of the derivative at a particular input. In contrast, finding the equation of the tangent line additionally requires knowing the value of the original function at that same input. In other words, the slope is just a number, whereas the equation incorporates additional information that together with the slope is sufficient to actually graph the tangent line.
Given a differentiable function y = f(x), we can express the derivative of f in several different notations: f'(x), \frac{df}{dx}, \frac{dy}{dx}, and \frac{d}{dx}[f(x)].

The limit definition of the derivative leads to patterns among certain families of functions. These patterns enable us to compute derivative formulas without resorting directly to the definition. For example, if f is a power function of the form f(x) = x^n for any real number n other than 0, then f'(x) = nx^{n-1}. This is called the rule for power functions.

We have stated a rule for derivatives of exponential functions in the same spirit as the rule for power functions: for any positive real number a, if f(x) = a^x, then f'(x) = a^x \ln(a). The graphical exploration in Example provides visual evidence for this rule as it shows that for an exponential function f(x)=a^x (a \gt 1), the graph of y=f'(x) appears to be a scaled version of the original function. In particular, careful analysis of the graph of y=2^x suggests that \frac{d}{dx}[2^x]=2^x\ln(2).

If we are given a constant multiple of a function whose derivative we know, or a sum of functions whose derivatives we know, the constant multiple and sum rules make it straightforward to compute the derivative of the overall function. More formally, if f(x) and g(x) are differentiable with derivatives f'(x) and g'(x) and if a and b are constants, then
\frac{d}{dx} \left[af(x) + bg(x)\right] = af'(x) + bg'(x) .

statement.p:
Let f and g be differentiable functions for which the following information is known: f(2) = 5, g(2) = -3, f'(2) = -1/2, g'(2) = 2.
Let h be the new function defined by the rule h(x) = 3f(x) - 4g(x). Determine h(2) and h'(2).
Find an equation for the tangent line to y = h(x) at the point (2,h(2)).
Let p be the function defined by the rule p(x) = -2f(x) + \frac{1}{2}g(x). Is p increasing, decreasing, or neither at a = 2? Why?
Estimate the value of p(2.03) by using the local linearization of p at the point (2,p(2)).

li.p: p is increasing at x=2.

First, since h(x) = 3f(x) - 4g(x), we know h(2) = 3f(2) - 4g(2) = 3(5) - 4(-3) = 27. Next, by the sum and constant multiple rules, h'(x) = 3f'(x) - 4g'(x). Hence, using the given derivative values, h'(2) = 3f'(2) - 4g'(2) = 3(-1/2) - 4(2) = -19/2.
The tangent line at the point (2,h(2)) has equation L(x) = h(2) + h'(2)(x-2). Using the information determined in (a), we see L(x) = 27 - \frac{19}{2}(x-2).

Since p(x) = -2f(x) + \frac{1}{2}g(x), it follows that p'(x) = -2f'(x) + \frac{1}{2}g'(x) by the sum and constant multiple rules. Using the given function and derivative values for f and g at x=2, we see that p(2) = -2f(2) + \frac{1}{2}g(2) = -2(5) + \frac{1}{2}(-3) = -\frac{23}{2} and p'(2) = -2(-\frac{1}{2}) + \frac{1}{2}(2)) = 2. Since p'(2) = 2 \gt 0, we conclude that p is increasing at x=2.

First, the linearization of p at a = 2 is L(x) = p(2) + p'(2)(x-2) = -\frac{23}{2} + 2(x-2). Using the linearization to estimate p(2.03), we find that
p(2.03) \approx L(2.03) = -\frac{23}{2} + 2(2.03-2) = -11.5 + 2(0.03) = -11.56 .

exercise.title: Calculating derivative values from two graphs

statement.p: Let functions p and q be the piecewise linear functions given by their respective graphs in Figure. Use the graphs to answer the following questions.

figure.caption: The graphs of p (in blue) and q (in green).

li.p: At what values of x is p not differentiable? At what values of x is q not differentiable? Why?
Let r(x) = p(x) + 2q(x). At what values of x is r not differentiable? Why?
Determine r'(-2) and r'(0).
Find an equation for the tangent line to y = r(x) at the point (2,r(2)).
p is not differentiable at x=-1 and x=1; q is not differentiable at x=-1 and x=1.
r is not differentiable at x=-1 and x=1.

The function p is differentiable at points where its graph is locally linear or smooth. Since there are sharp corners in the graph of p at x=-1 and x=1, we see that p is not differentiable at those points. Similarly, the sharp corners in q at x=-1 and x=1 mean that q is not differentiable at these points, either.
In order for r to be differentiable at a point, both p and q must be differentiable at the point. So r is not differentiable at x=-1 and x=1.

Using the sum and scalar multiple rules, we have r'(x) = p'(x) + 2q'(x). The slope of p at x=-2 is -2 and the slope of q at x=-2 is 3, so p'(-2) = -2 and q'(-2) = 3. It follows that '(-2) = p'(-2) + 2q'(-2) = (-2) + 2(3) = 4. Similarly, the slope of p at x=0 is 1 and the slope of q at x=0 is 0, so p'(0) = 1 and q'(0) = 0. It follows that r'(0) = p'(0) + 2q'(0) = (1) + 2(0) = 1.
Note that r(2) = p(2)+2q(2) = 2+2(1) = 4 and r'(2) = p'(2)+2q'(2) = 2+2(-1) = 0. Thus, the line tangent to the graph of r at x=2 is y = r(2) + r'(2)(x-2) = 4.

exercise.title: Using the sum and constant multiple rules

statement.p:
Consider the functions r(t) = t^t and s(t) = \arccos(t), for which you are given the facts that r'(t) = t^t(\ln(t) + 1) and s'(t) = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t^2}}. Do not be concerned with where these derivative formulas come from. We restrict our interest in both functions to the domain 0 \lt t \lt 1.
Let w(t) = 3t^t - 2\arccos(t). Determine w'(t).
Find an equation for the tangent line to y = w(t) at the point (\frac{1}{2}, w(\frac{1}{2})).
Let v(t) = t^t + \arccos(t). Is v increasing or decreasing at the instant t = \frac{1}{2}? Why?

li.p: v is increasing at t = \frac{1}{2}.

We note that w has the structure w(t) = 3r(t) - 2s(t), so by the sum and constant multiple rules, w'(t) = 3r'(t) - 2s'(t). Applying the given information about r' and s', w'(t) = 3t^t(\ln(t) + 1) + 2\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t^2}}.

We see that w(\frac{1}{2}) = 3(\frac{1}{2})^{\frac{1}{2}} - 2\arccos(\frac{1}{2}) = 3 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} - 2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{3} = \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}} - \frac{2\pi}{3}. Similarly,
w'\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) &= 3\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + 1\right) + 2\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(\frac{1}{2})^2}} &= \frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + 1\right) + \frac{4}{\sqrt{3}} . Using these values, we find that the tangent line to w at the point (\frac{1}{2},w(\frac{1}{2}) is
L(t) = w\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + w'\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(t-\frac{1}{2}\right) = \left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{2}} - \frac{2\pi}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{3}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + 1\right) + \frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}\right)(t-2) .

To determine whether v is increasing or decreasing at t = \frac{1}{2}, we compute v'(\frac{1}{2}). First, v'(t) = t^t(\ln(t) + 1) + \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-t^2}}. Hence,
v'\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) = \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\ln\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + 1\right) + \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-(\frac{1}{2})^2}} . Since (\ln(\frac{1}{2})+1) is positive, it's clear that v'(\frac{1}{2}) \gt 0, and thus v is increasing at t = \frac{1}{2}.

exercise.title: Understanding the derivative of an exponential function

statement.p:
Let f(x) = a^x. The goal of this problem is to explore how the value of a affects the derivative of f(x), without assuming we know the rule for \frac{d}{dx}[a^x] that we have stated and used in earlier work in this section.
Use the limit definition of the derivative to show that
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^x \cdot a^h - a^x}{h} .
Explain why it is also true that
f'(x) = a^x \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^h - 1}{h} .
Use computing technology and small values of h to estimate the value of
L = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^h - 1}{h}
when a = 2. Do likewise when a = 3.
Note that it would be ideal if the value of the limit L was 1, for then f would be a particularly special function: its derivative would be simply a^x, which would mean that its derivative is itself. By experimenting with different values of a between 2 and 3, try to find a value for a for which
L = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^h - 1}{h} = 1 .
Compute \ln(2) and \ln(3). What does your work in (b) and (c) suggest is true about \frac{d}{dx}[2^x] and \frac{d}{dx}[3^x]?
How do your investigations in (d) lead to a particularly important fact about the function f(x) = e^x?

li.p: Since a^x does not depend at all on h, we may treat a^x as constant in the noted limit and thus write the value a^x in front of the limit being taken.
When a = 2, L \approx 0.6931; when a = 3, L \approx 1.0986.
a \approx 2.71828 (for which L \approx 1.000)

\frac{d}{dx}[2^x] = 2^x \cdot \ln(2)
and
\frac{d}{dx}[3^x] = 3^x \cdot \ln(3)
\frac{d}{dx}[e^x] = e^x .

Since a^x does not depend at all on h, we may treat a^x as constant in the noted limit. Thus,
f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^{x}(a^{h}-1)}{h} = a^{x} \cdot \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^{h}-1}{h} . Note that this tells us that the derivative of a^x is some constant multiple of a^x (and that the constant's values must be \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^{h}-1}{h}.)
Using h = \pm 0.0001, it appears that when a = 2, L \approx 0.6931, while when a = 3, L \approx 1.0986.

By experimenting, we see first that a \approx 2.7 (for which L \approx 0.993, so a needs to be slightly bigger than 2.7). Continuing to try values of a that result in L being closer and closer to 1, we find a \approx 2.71828 (for which L \approx 1.000)

We note that \ln(2) \approx 0.6931 and \ln(3) \approx 1.0986. Since these values correspond to the values of
\lim_{h \to 0} \frac{a^{h}-1}{h}
when a = 2 and a = 3, we conjecture that
\frac{d}{dx}[2^x] = 2^x \cdot \ln(2)
and
\frac{d}{dx}[3^x] = 3^x \cdot \ln(3)

Our work suggests that \frac{d}{dx}[a^x] = a^x \cdot \ln(a), and when a = e \approx 2.71828, it follows that
\frac{d}{dx}[e^x] = e^x \cdot \ln(e) = e^x
Thus, e^x is a very special function: its derivative is itself!
